title: 110_hr769
content: The "National Language Act of 2007" establishes English as the official language of the government. The "National Language Act of 2007" declares English as the official language of the United States government for all official activities, publications, and communication. It aims to preserve and enhance the role of English as the official language, with limited exceptions specified by law. The "National Language Act of 2007" establishes English as the official language of the United States government, with limited exceptions for religious purposes, foreign language training, and language programs in schools. Any use of languages other than English does not create a legal entitlement to additional services. The chapter allows the US government to provide interpreters for individuals over 62 years old. The chapter repeals bilingual voting requirements. The chapter repeals bilingual voting requirements and amends sections of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, including the repeal of Section 203 and the amendment of Section 4 by striking subsection (f). Conforming amendments are made to references to Section 203 and Section 4 within the Act. The Reauthorization and Amendments Act of 2006 makes amendments to various sections of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 by removing certain language related to guarantees and declaratory judgments. The Reauthorization and Amendments Act of 2006 amended sections of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 related to denials or abridgments of the right to vote. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require all citizenship ceremonies to be conducted in English. This Act does not preempt any state laws.
